example[0]: Smoking is the prime cause of lung disease.
example[1]: Our prime concern is providing jobs for all young school leavers.
example[2]: He was named as the prime suspect in the murder investigation.
example[3]: Good management is of prime importance in business.
definition[1]: of the very best quality or kind
example[6]: The hotel is in a prime location overlooking the valley.
definition[2]: the time in your life when you are strongest and most active
example[7]: He is now past his prime.
example[8]: a man in the prime of life
example[9]: a young singer who was tragically cut off in her prime (=died while she was in her prime)
example[10]: She’s now 40 and still in her prime.
definition[3]: to prepare someone for a situation so that they know what to do
example[11]: Did you prime her with what to say?
example[12]: He had a shower and primed himself for action.
example[13]: He had been primed to say nothing about it.
definition[4]: to prepare a gun or bomb so that it can fire or explode
definition[5]: to put a special layer of paint on a surface, in order to prepare it for the next layer
example[14]: All metal surfaces will have to be primed.
definition[6]: to pour water into a water pump in order to make it ready to work
example[15]: acres of prime real estate right by an international airport
example[16]: The developer’s prime objective is to build houses at maximum profit, with minimum care for the environment.
example[17]: their prime concern was for the safety of the international financial system.
example[18]: Martin Marietta Corp., the prime contractor in the rocket-engine development program
definition[9]: to make the economy grow faster by increasing government spending, hoping that this will encourage business to invest more
example[19]: Direct investments in job creation are essential to prime the pump and get the economy up and running again.
definition[10]: used to talk about how much higher an interest rate is than the PRIME RATE (=the interest rate charged by banks to their best borrowers)
example[20]: The working-capital loan carried an interest rate of 3½ points above prime.
